intro: Anethum graveolens subsp. sowa, commonly known as Sowa cumin, is a member of the Apiaceae family and is native to the Himalayan regions of Nepal and India. This subspecies is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in umbels. The plant produces aromatic, oblong seeds that are widely used in traditional medicine and as a spice. Its botanical features include pinnately compound leaves and a taproot system, which help it thrive in high-altitude environments. Sowa cumin is valued for its essential oils, which contain compounds like cuminaldehyde and limonene, contributing to its distinctive flavor and medicinal properties.
